title: Which authors would you suggest to someone who wants to read Victorian literature? - Quora

response.answer_text: - Algernon Charles Swinburne - a versifier who vies with Shelley, Keats, and (occasionally) Shakespeare. - William Morris was a Renaissance man who, among all sorts of other pursuits, wrote novels and epic poetry. Check him out. - Anthony Trollope - gives you a comprehensive view of English society from 10,000 feet in the air - Charlotte Bronte - a tremendous writer and one of the first anti-Romanticists (read Jane Eyre and you'll see what I’m talking about) - Robert Browning and Elizabeth Barrett Browning - Dante Gabriel Rossetti and Christina Rosetti - George Borrow - Lavengro and The Romany Rye - George Meredith - The Egoist - George Saintsbury - was a tremendous, albeit somewhat conservative-minded critic. - Arthur Symons was ammuch more progressive critic. Read Saintsbury for everything before Flaubert. read Symons for everything after Flaubert. -Get a taste (just a taste) of Charles Lever and Captain Marryat

Charles Dickens would certainly top my list. I’d also add William Thackeray and George Elliot (actually Mary Ann Evans, but it was hard for a woman to get published in those days). Other well known Victorian writers are the Brontë sisters, Emily being perhaps the most famous for her Wuthering Heights, but Charlotte should not be ignored for her fine novels Villette and Jane Eyre. I’d also recommend Anthony Trollope who wrote a whole series of novels collectively known as the Barsetshire chronicles. (The first one is called The Warden, and is a fine example of his writing.) And one should certainly not neglect Thomas Hardy, whose novels Tess of the d’Urbervilles and The Mayor of Casterbridge are excellent examples of his writing.
